data.title: Sanz sets the pace
data.meta_description: The Latin Grammys took a page from their parent's history book Wednesday night at the Shrine Auditorium, rewarding a single performer early and often.
data.text:
See Winners

The Latin Grammys took a page from their parent’s history book Wednesday night at the Shrine Auditorium, rewarding a single performer early and often.

As Norah Jones did most recently, Alejandro Sanz stormed through the major categories, taking home awards for album of the year, record of the year and best male pop vocal album for his record “No Es Lo Mismo” and song of the year (songwriter for the title track).

Engineer/mixer Mick Guzauski was three for three, walking away with album, record and engineered album of the year, also for “No Es Lo Mismo.”

Maria Rita, nommed for six, won two kudos for best new artist and MPB (Musica Popular Brasileira) album of the year for her debut Brazilian record, “Maria Rita.” Songwriter Milton Nascimento nabbed Brazilian song (Portuguese language) kudos for Rita’s track “A Festa.”

Popular on Variety

“I had no expectations coming in today,” said Maria Rita. “For a Brazilian to be nominated (so many times) in the general category, it’s really very good. It’s great for Brazilian music and musicians in general.”

It was a disappointing evening for producer Tom Capone, who had been nominated in six categories but walked away empty-handed. Instead, producer of the year went to Javier Limon.

Celia Cruz won best salsa album for “Regalo Del Alma” posthumously; the Cuban singer died of cancer in July 2003.

Hosting the kudofest for the second consecutive year, George Lopez arrived on horseback, joking as he rode in, “(This is) the way we have to get around in Los Angeles since Gov. Schwarzenegger took away our driver’s licenses.”

Lopez continued the ribbing, commenting that “people like Schwarzenegger because he makes George Bush seem like he’s Hooked on Phonics.”

In an attempt to attract younger — and Anglo — auds the two-hour CBS broadcast featured consistent Latino-Anglo pairing of both performers and presenters. Jessica Simpson, just back from the MTV Video Music Awards in Miami, opened the show with a Spanish-English duet, performed with pop star David Bisbal. While Incubus shared the stage with Cafe Tecuba, presenters included couple of the moment Lindsay Lohan and Wilmer Valderrama, as well as Amber Tamblyn and Jason Ritter.

But it was Carlos Santana’s performance of “La Bamba” and “I Don’t Wanna Lose Your Love” with Los Lonely Boys that brought the crowd to their feet. Santana, who was named 2004 Person of the Year by the Acad on Monday night, had little to say after the performance. Introducing the Los Lonely Boys as “the future of music,” he added, “They’re so good they don’t even know how to lip-sync.”

Ultimately, only eight of the 43 award categories were unveiled on the air, as the 35 additional awards were announced just prior to showtime. Telecast was blipped to 105 countries. Eligibility period was for recordings shipped between April 1, 2003, and March 31, 2004.

Awards were presented by the Latin Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences on Wednesday night at the Shrine Auditorium.

And the winners are…

5th Annual Latin Grammy Awards. For recordings released during the eligibility period of April 1, 2003, through March 31, 2004.

Record Of The Year (Award to the Artist and to the Producer(s), Recording Engineer(s) and/or Mixer(s) if other than the artist. Singles or tracks only.)

“No Es Lo Mismo,” Alejandro Sanz. Lulo Pérez & Alejandro Sanz, producers; Mick Guzauski & Rafa Sardina, engineers/mixers. Track from: “No Es Lo Mismo” (Warner Music Latina)

Album Of The Year (Award to the Artist(s), and to the Album Producer(s), Recording Engineer(s) / Mixer(s) & Mastering Engineer(s) if other than the artist.)

“No Es Lo Mismo,” Alejandro Sanz. Lulo Pérez & Alejandro Sanz, producers; Mick Guzauski, Bob Ludwig, Rafa Sardina & Pepo Sherman, engineers/mixers; Bob Ludwig, mastering engineer (Warner Music Latina)

Song Of The Year (A Songwriter(s) Award. A song must contain melody and lyrics in Spanish or Portuguese and must be either a new song or a song first achieving prominence during the Eligibility Year. Singles or tracks only.)

“No Es Lo Mismo,” Alejandro Sanz, songwriter (Alejandro Sanz). Track from: “No Es Lo Mismo” (Warner Music Latin)

New Artist (For a new artist who releases, during the Eligibility Year, the first recording which establishes the public identity of that artist. Albums only.)

Maria Rita

Female Pop Vocal Album

“De Mil Colores,” Rosario (Ariola Records/BMG Music Spain)

Male Pop Vocal Album

“No Es Lo Mismo,” Alejandro Sanz (Warner Music Latina)

Pop Album By A Duo Or Group With Vocal

“De Viaje,” Sin Bandera (Sony Discos)

Urban Music Album

“En Honor A La Verdad,” Vico C (EMI Latin)

Rock Solo Vocal Album

“Sí,” Julieta Venegas (Ariola/BMG Mexico)

Rock Album By A Duo Or Group With Vocal

“Libertad,” La Ley (Warner Music Mexico)

Alternative Music Album

“Cuatro Caminos,” Café Tacuba (Universal Music Mexico)

Rock Song (A Songwriter(s) Award. Includes Rock & Alternative Rock. A song must contain melody and lyrics and must be either a new song or a song first achieving prominence during the Eligibility Year. Singles or tracks only.)

“Eres,” Emmanuel Del Real, songwriter (Café Tacuba). Track from: “Cuatro Caminos” (Universal Music Mexico)

Salsa Album

“Regalo Del Alma,” Celia Cruz (Sony Music)

Merengue Album

“Sin Desperdicio,” Johnny Ventura (Musical Productions)

Contemporary Tropical Album

“Albita Llegó,” Albita (Angels’ Dawn Records)

Traditional Tropical Album

“Lágrimas Negras,” Bebo Valdés y Diego El Cigala (Calle 54 Records/BMG Records)

Tropical Song (A Songwriter(s) Award. A song must contain melody and lyrics and must be either a new song or a song first achieving prominence during the Eligibility Year. Singles or tracks only. )

“Ríe y Llora,” Sergio George & Fernando Osorio, songwriters (Celia Cruz). Track from: Regalo Del Alma (Sony Music)

Singer-Songwriter Album (For solo artists or duos. Albums only.)

“Soraya,” Soraya (EMI Latin)

Ranchero Album

“En Vivo Juntos Por Ultima Vez,” Vicente y Alejandro Fernández (Sony Discos)

Banda Album

“Por Ti,” Banda El Recodo de Cruz Lizárraga (Fonovisa Records/Univision Music Group)

Grupero Album

“Cuando El Corazón Se Cruza,” Alicia Villarreal (Mercury Records/Universal Music Group)

Tejano Album

“Live En El Valle,” Jimmy González y Grupo Mazz (Freddie Records)

Norteño Album

“Pacto De Sangre,” Los Tigres Del Norte (Fonovisa Records/Univision Music Group)

Regional Mexican Song (A Songwriter(s) Award. A song must contain melody and lyrics and must be either a new song or a song first achieving prominence during the Eligibility Year. Singles or Tracks only.)

“Tu Amor O Tu Desprecio,” Marco Antonio Solís, songwriter (Marco Antonio Solís). Track from: Tu Amor O Tu Desprecio (Fonovisa Records)

Instrumental Album

“Obrigado Brazil Live In Concert,” Yo-Yo Ma (Sony Classical)

Folk Album

” K,” Kepa Junkera (EMI-Odeon SA)

Tango Album

“Postangos En Vivo En Rosario,” Gerardo Gandini (EPSA Musi)

Flamenco Album

“Cositas Buenas,” Paco De Lucía (Universal Music Spain)

Latin Jazz Album

“New Conceptions,” Chucho Valdés (Blue Note)

Christian Album (Spanish Language)

“Recordando Otra Vez,” Marcos Witt (CanZion/Sony Disco)

Christian Album (Portuguese Language)

“Fruto De Amor,” Aline Barros (AB Records)

Brazilian Contemporary Pop Album

“Carlinhos Brown Es Carlito Marrón,” Carlinhos Brown (Ariola Records/BMG Music Spain)

Brazilian Rock Album

“Cosmotron,” Skank (Epic Records)

Samba/Pagode Album

“Para Caymmi. De Nana, Dori e Danilo,” Nana, Dori e Danilo (Warner Music Brasil)

MPB (Musica Popular Brasileira) Album

“Maria Rita,” Maria Rita (Warner Music Brasil)

Romantic Music Album

“Zezé Di Camargo & Luciano,” Zezé Di Camargo & Luciano (Columbia Records)

Brazilian Roots/Regional Album

“No Século XXI No Pátio Do Forró,” Banda De Pífanos De Caruaru (Trama)

Brazilian Song (Portuguese Language) (A Songwriter(s) Award. A song must contain melody and lyrics and must be either a new song or a song first achieving prominence during the Eligibility Year. Singles or Tracks only.)

“A Festa,” Milton Nascimento, songwriter (Maria Rita). Track from: “Maria Rita” (Warner Music Brasil)

Latin Children’s Album

“Niños Adorando 2,” Niños Adorando. Coalo Zamorano, producer (CanZion)

Classical Album – TIE (Award to the Artist(s) and to the Album Producer(s) if other than the artist. Albums Only.)

“Carmen Symphony,” Orquestra Simfònica De Barcelona I Nacional De Catalunya & José Serebrier; Robert Suff, producer (Bis Music)

“Jobim Sinfônico,” Varios Artistas; Mario Adnet & Paulo Jobim, producers (Biscoito Fino)

Engineered Album

“No Es Lo Mismo,” Rafa Sardina, Mick Guzauski, Pepo Sherman, engineers (Alejandro Sanz) (Warner Music Latina)

Engineered Album

Javier Limón
